ca.uqac.lif.cep

Interface Pullable

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    EmlPuller.EmlPullable, GroupProcessor.ProxyPullable, Last.SentinelPullable, Multiplexer.MuxPullable, SingleProcessor.OutputPullable, SmartFork.QueuePullable, TypedPullable

    public interface Pullable
    Queries events on one of a processor's outputs. For a processor with an output arity n, there exists n distinct pullables, namely one for each output trace. Every pullable works roughly like a classical Iterator: it is possible to check whether new output events are available, and get one new output event.

    However, contrarily to iterators, Pullables have two versions of each method: a soft and a hard version.

    • Soft methods make a single attempt at producing an output event. Since processors are connected in a chain, this generally means pulling events from the input in order to produce the output. However, if pulling the input produces no event, no output event can be produced. In such a case, hasNext() will return a special value (MAYBE), and pull() will return null. Soft methods can be seen a doing "one turn of the crank" on the whole chain of processors --whether or not this outputs something.
    • Hard methods are actually calls to soft methods until an output event is produced: the "crank" is turned as long as necessary to produce something. This means that one call to, e.g. pullHard() may consume more than one event from a processor's input. Therefore, calls to hasNextHard() never return MAYBE (only YES or NO), and pullHard() returns null only if no event will ever be output in the future (this occurs, for example, when pulling events from a file, and the end of the file has been reached).

    The lifecycle of a Pullable object is as follows:

    • One obtains a reference to one of a processor's pullables. This can be done explicitly, e.g. by calling Processor.getPullableOutput(int), or implicitly, for example through every call to Connector.connect(Processor...).
    • At various moments, one calls hasNext() (or hasNextHard() to check if events are available
    • One calls pull() (or pullHard() to produce the next available output event.

    For the same processor, mixing calls to soft and hard methods is discouraged. As a matter of fact, the Pullable's behaviour in such a situation is left undefined.

    Author:
    Sylvain Hallé

      The "next" status of the pullable.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static int s_maxRetries
      Number of times the hasNextHard() method tries to produce an output from the input before giving up.

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      int getPosition()
      Gets the position this Pullable is associated to: 0 is the first input (or output), 1 the second, etc.
      Processor getProcessor()
      Gets the processor instance this Pullable is linked to
      int getPullCount()
      Gets the number of events pulled so far
      Pullable.NextStatus hasNext()
      Determines if an event can be pulled from the output.
      Pullable.NextStatus hasNextHard()
      Determines if an event can be pulled from the output, by trying "harder" than hasNext().
      Object pull()
      Attempts to pull an event from the source.
      Object pullHard()
      Attempts to pull an event from the source.

    • Field Detail

      • s_maxRetries

        static final int s_maxRetries
        Number of times the hasNextHard() method tries to produce an output from the input before giving up. While in theory, the method tries "as long as necessary", in practice a bound was put on the number of attempts as a safeguard to avoid infinite loops.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • pull

        Object pull()
        Attempts to pull an event from the source. An event is returned if hasNext() returns YES, and null is returned otherwise.
        Returns:
        An event, or null if none could be retrieved

      • pullHard

        Object pullHard()
        Attempts to pull an event from the source. An event is returned if hasNextHard() returns YES, and null is returned otherwise.
        Returns:
        An event, or null if none could be retrieved

      • hasNext

        Pullable.NextStatus hasNext()
        Determines if an event can be pulled from the output. Depending on what happens, the possible return values are:
        • If one of the inputs answers "no" when called for hasNext(), returns "no"
        • If one of the inputs answers "maybe" when called for hasNext(), returns "maybe"
        • If all inputs answer "yes" when called for hasNext(), but no event is produced with the given inputs, returns "maybe"
        • Otherwise, returns "yes"
        Therefore, the method is lazy in that it asks events from its input only once, and attempts to produce an output event only once.
        Returns:
        Whether a next event exists

      • hasNextHard

        Pullable.NextStatus hasNextHard()
        Determines if an event can be pulled from the output, by trying "harder" than hasNext(). Depending on what happens, the possible return values are:
        • If one of the inputs answers "no" when called for hasNext(), returns "no"
        • If all inputs answer "yes" when called for hasNext(), and an event is produced with the given inputs, returns "yes"
        • Otherwise, the method will keep calling hasNextHard() on the inputs as long as they don't answer "no", and will try to produce an output event until one is produced.
        • To avoid infinite looping, the method eventually gives up (and answers "no") after some maximum number of repetitions is reached. This is configured by the static field s_maxRetries.
        Returns:
        Whether a next event exists

      • getPullCount

        int getPullCount()
        Gets the number of events pulled so far
        Returns:
        The number of events

      • getProcessor

        Processor getProcessor()
        Gets the processor instance this Pullable is linked to
        Returns:
        The processor

      • getPosition

        int getPosition()
        Gets the position this Pullable is associated to: 0 is the first input (or output), 1 the second, etc.
        Returns:
        The position
